facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 891 of 1963 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 891 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated June 26, 1959 of Assam High Court in Letter Patent Appeal No. 1 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated June 26, 1959 of the Assam High Court in Letter Patent Appeal No. 1 of 1959.

facts.text: Biswambar Roy, predecessor of appellants, was granted a lease on February 20, 1928 for ten years from 1335 B.S. to 1344 B.S. at Rs. 75/- annual rental for plot of land part of Dag No. 3615 in Silchar, Cachar, Assam.

anchor.surface_text: Biswambar Roy-predecessor-interest of the appellants--was Granted on February 20, 1928, a lease for ten years 1335 B.S. to 1344 B.S. at an annual rental of Rs. 75/- in respect of a plot of land, part of Dag No. 3615 in the town of Silchar, District Cachar in the State of Assam.

facts.text: Biswambar Roy constructed buildings on the land, some for residential use and others as warehouses.

anchor.surface_text: Biswambar Roy companystructed on the land, buildings, some for residential use, and others as warehouses.

facts.text: Biswambar Roy obtained a fresh lease on February 22, 1938 for a part of the land for ten years from Baisakh 1345 B.S. to Chaitra 1354 B.S. at Rs. 70/- annual rental.

anchor.surface_text: On the expiry of the period of the original lease, Biswambar Roy obtained a fresh lease in respect of a part of the land for ten years- Baisakh 1345 B.S. to Chaitra a 1354 B.S. at an annual rental of Rs. 70/- under an instrument dated February 22, 1938.

facts.text: Respondents purchased the interest of the landlords in the land.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents purchased the interest of the landlords the land and instituted on August 3, 1951 an action in the Court of the Sadar Munsiff, Silchar against Biswambar Roy for a decree for vacant possession of the land.

facts.text: Respondents instituted suit on August 3, 1951 in Court of Sadar Munsiff, Silchar against Biswambar Roy for vacant possession of the land.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents purchased the interest of the landlords the land and instituted on August 3, 1951 an action in the Court of the Sadar Munsiff, Silchar against Biswambar Roy for a decree for vacant possession of the land.

facts.text: Suit decreed by Munsiff in favour of respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was decreed by the Munsiff.

facts.text: Biswambar Roy appealed to Subordinate Judge, Silchar.

anchor.surface_text: Biswambar Roy appealed to the Subordinate Judge, Silchar.

facts.text: During pendency of appeal, Non-agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act 12 of 1955 was enacted by Assam Legislature and brought into force.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the appeal, the Non-agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act 12 of 1955 enacted by the Assam Legislature was brought into force.

facts.text: Biswambar Roy claimed protection from eviction under s. 3 of Act 12 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Biswambar Roy claimed protection from eviction under s. 3 of Act 12 of 1955.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held Biswambar Roy acquired rights of permanent tenant under s. 5(1)(a) as he constructed permanent structures for residential or business purposes, reversed trial court decree and dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge held that Biswambar Roy had acquired under s. 5 1  a  of the Act the rights of a permanent tenant, since he had companystructed within the period prescribed permanent structures for residential or business purposes. He accordingly reversed the decree passed by the Trial Court and dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Appeal preferred to High Court of Assam against Subordinate Judge's decree.

anchor.surface_text: Against that decree, an appeal was preferred to the High Court of Assam.

facts.text: Deka J. of Assam High Court held Biswambar Roy could not claim protection of s.5(1)(a) since he let out buildings to tenants.

anchor.surface_text: Deka, J., held that Biswambar Roy companyld number claim the protection of s. 5 1   a  of the Act, since he had- let out to tenants the buildings companystructed on the land.

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal heard by C.P. Sinha CJ and Mehrotra J. who differed: Sinha CJ held protection applies, Mehrotra J held no as not for own use.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal under the Letters Patent from that judgment was heard by C. P. Sinha, C. J., and Mehrotra, J. The learned Judges differed. Sinha, C. J., was of the view that permanent structures companystructed by Biswambar Roy companyformed to the descripticon residential or business purposes and Biswambar Roy became under Act 12 of 1955 a permanent tenant thereof and was number liable to be evicted except for number- payment of rent. With that view Mehrotra, J., did number agree.

facts.text: High Court Letters Patent Appeal dismissed under s.98(2) CPC due to no majority.

anchor.surface_text: Since there was numbermajority companycurring in the judgment agreeing or reversing the decree appealed from, under s. 98 2  of the Code of Civil Procedure the appeal was ordered to be dismissed.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court preferred with special leave against High Court decree.

anchor.surface_text: Against the decree passed by the High Court, with special leave, this appeal is preferred.

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.5 of Assam Act 12 of 1955 has retrospective operation citing Refiquennessa v. Lal Bahadur Chetri.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held that s. 5 of Assam Act 12 of 1955 has retrospective operation Refiquennessa v. Lal Bahadur Chetri Others, 1  and the only question to be determined in this appeal is whether a tenant qualifies for protection under s. 5 of the Act only after building permanent structures on the land of the tenancy if he occupies them for his own residential or business purposes.

facts.text: Biswambar Roy let out the buildings constructed on the land to tenants.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the learned Judge, by the use of the expression for residential or business purposes in s. 5 1  a  it is intended that buildings companystructed by the tenant should be utilized by the tenant himself for his own residence or for carrying on business and that it is number the intention of the Legislature that third persons should be protected by s. 5 from eviction from those structures.

facts.text: First two conditions of s.5(1)(a) fulfilled: entitled to build under contract and built within 5 years.

anchor.surface_text: The first two companyditions are fulfilled in this case. But the learned Judges of the High Court disagreed on the fulfillment of the third companydition they differed as to the true meaning of the expression a permanent structure for residential or business purposes.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that protection under s.5(1)(a) available if permanent structure adapted for residential or business purposes, not requiring personal use by tenant.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the view taken by Mehrotra, J., because the Legislature has number, in companyferring rights of permanent tenancy, either expressly or by implication enacted any such qualification as is suggested by the learned Judge. The section merely requires that the permanent structure must be one adapted for residential or business purposes.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, vacated High Court decree, dismissed plaintiffs' suit.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is therefore allowed and the decree passed by the High Court vacated and the plaintiffs suit dismissed. The appellants who are the representatives of the tenant will be entitled to their companyts in this Court.

facts.text: Appellants are representatives of the tenant Biswambar Roy.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants who are the representatives of the tenant will be entitled to their companyts in this Court.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated June 26, 1959 of the Assam High Court in Letter Patent Appeal No. 1 of 1959.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated June 26, 1959 of the Assam High Court in Letter Patent Appeal No. 1 of 1959. C. Chatterjee and D. N. Mukherjee, for the appellants.
Since there was numbermajority companycurring in the judgment agreeing or reversing the decree appealed from, under s. 98 2  of the Code of Civil Procedure the appeal was ordered to be dismissed.

issues.text: whether a tenant qualifies for protection under s. 5 of the Act only after building permanent structures on the land of the tenancy if he occupies them for his own residential or business purposes

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held that s. 5 of Assam Act 12 of 1955 has retrospective operation Refiquennessa v. Lal Bahadur Chetri Others, 1  and the only question to be determined in this appeal is whether a tenant qualifies for protection under s. 5 of the Act only after building permanent structures on the land of the tenancy if he occupies them for his own residential or business purposes.

issues.text: the true meaning of the expression a permanent structure for residential or business purposes

anchor.surface_text: The first two conditions are fulfilled in this case. But the learned Judges of the High Court disagreed on the fulfillment of the third condition they differed as to the true meaning of the expression a permanent structure for residential or business purposes. In the view of Sinha, C. J., under the Act the character of the structure is determinative and not personal use by the tenant.

He accordingly reversed the decree passed by the Trial Court and dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: With that view Mehrotra, J., did number agree. He held that a tenant who obtains land on lease for erecting a structure thereon number for his own residential or business purposes but for letting out to others does number build a permanent structure on the land of, the tenancy for residential or business purposes. and may number claim protec- tion under s. 5 1  a .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: protection. By merely letting the premises companystructed on the land obtained by him on lease, the tenant does number cease to be in possession of t

arguments.claim: Section 5 of Assam Act 12 of 1955 has retrospective operation

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held that s. 5 of Assam Act 12 of 1955 has retrospective operation Refiquennessa v. Lal Bahadur Chetri Others, 1

arguments.claim: Protection under s.5(1)(a) available where tenant entitled to build under contract, built within 5 years a permanent structure adapted for residential or business purposes; no requirement of personal occupation or use by tenant

anchor.surface_text: Protection under the first part of s. 5 1  a  may be claimed by a tenant if three companyditions companyexist  i  under the terms of the companytract of tenancy the tenant is entitled to build on the land of the tenancy  ii  that pursuant to such liberty, he has actually built, within the period of five years from the date of the companytract a permanent structure on the land of the tenancy and  iii  that the permanent structure is for residential or business purposes. The first two companyditions are fulfilled in this case.

arguments.claim: The expression 'permanent structure on the land of the tenancy for residential or business purposes' means permanent structure adapted for residential or business purposes; reading it to require construction for tenant's own use adds words not in the section

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the view taken by Mehrotra, J., because the Legislature has number, in companyferring rights of permanent tenancy, either expressly or by implication enacted any such qualification as is suggested by the learned Judge. The section merely requires that the permanent structure must be one adapted for residential or business purposes. If the structure is number adapted to such purposes, the protection of s. 5 1  a  will number be available.

arguments.claim: By letting out the premises constructed on the land, the tenant does not cease to be in possession of the land; relation of landlord and tenant continues; structure does not cease to be for residential or business purposes

anchor.surface_text: By merely letting the premises companystructed on the land obtained by him on lease, the tenant does number cease to be in possession of the land. The relation between the landlord and the tenant of the land companytinues to subsist until it is lawfully determined. Possession of the land obtained by the tenant remains his even after he has let out the building companystructed by him, and a building companystructed by the tenant for use as residential or business purposes does number cease to be one for residential or business purposes, when it is let out.

holdings.text: s. 5 of Assam Act 12 of 1955 has retrospective operation

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held that s. 5 of Assam Act 12 of 1955 has retrospective operation Refiquennessa v. Lal Bahadur Chetri Others, 1  and the only question to be determined in this appeal is whether a tenant qualifies for protection under s. 5 of the Act only after building permanent structures on the land of the tenancy if he occupies them for his own residential or business purposes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relies on prior Supreme Court precedent in Refiquennessa v. Lal Bahadur Chetri

holdings.text: The first two conditions of s.5(1)(a) are fulfilled in this case

anchor.surface_text: The first two conditions are fulfilled in this case. But the learned Judges of the High Court disagreed on the fulfillment of the third condition they differed as to the true meaning of the expression a permanent structure for residential or business purposes. In the view of Sinha, C. J., under the Act the character of the structure is determinative and not personal use by the tenant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract entitled tenant to build and construction occurred within five years of contract

holdings.text: The section merely requires that the permanent structure must be one adapted for residential or business purposes; personal occupation or use by the tenant himself is not required

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the view taken by Mehrotra, J., because the Legislature has number, in companyferring rights of permanent tenancy, either expressly or by implication enacted any such qualification as is suggested by the learned Judge. The section merely requires that the permanent structure must be one adapted for residential or business purposes. If the structure is number adapted to such purposes, the protection of s. 5 1  a  will number be available.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal reading of statutory text without adding unexpressed qualifications for personal use; rejects purposive addition of words not present

holdings.text: To read the expression permanent structure on the land of the tenancy for residential or business purposes as meaning permanent structure constructed by the tenant for his own residential or business purposes is to add words which are not found in the section

anchor.surface_text: To read the expression permanent  1  1964 6 S.C.R. 876. structure on the land of the tenancy for residential or business purposes as meaning permanent structure on the land of the tenancy companystructed by the tenant for his own residential or business purposes is to add words which are number found in the section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strict textual interpretation prohibits implying or inserting additional requirements beyond plain language

holdings.text: the argument is wholly misconceived. Protection is conferred in terms by s. 5 upon the tenant of the land and not upon the tenant of the buildings constructed upon the land

anchor.surface_text: It was urged on behalf of the landlords that it companyld number have been the intention of the Legislature to companyfer by s. 5 1  a  protection upon sub-tenants. It was said that a sub-tenant is number a tenant within the meaning of s. 3 g  of the Act, and he cannot claim protection from eviction under s. 5 1  a . In our judgment, the argument is wholly misconceived.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory protection targets tenant's interest in land, not derivative interests in superstructures

holdings.text: By merely letting the premises constructed on the land obtained by him on lease, the tenant does not cease to be in possession of the land

anchor.surface_text: By merely letting the premises companystructed on the land obtained by him on lease, the tenant does number cease to be in possession of the land. The relation between the landlord and the tenant of the land companytinues to subsist until it is lawfully determined. Possession of the land obtained by the tenant remains his even after he has let out the building companystructed by him,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Landlord-tenant relationship over land persists despite sub-letting of structures; possession of land remains with tenant

holdings.text: We therefore agree with the view taken by Sinha, C. J., that the protection of s. 5 1  a  extends to a tenant who has companystructed on the land obtained on lease permanent structures which are adapted for use for residential or business purposes and by letting out the structures the tenant does number forfeit the protection companyferred by the statute

anchor.surface_text: We therefore agree with the view taken by Sinha, C. J., that the protection of s. 5 1  a  extends to a tenant who has companystructed on the land obtained on lease permanent structures which are adapted for use for residential or business purposes and by letting out the structures the tenant does number forfeit the protection companyferred by the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All statutory conditions met on facts; aligns with Sinha CJ's interpretation over dissenting views

precedents.citation: Refiquennessa v. Lal Bahadur Chetri Others, 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held that s. 5 of Assam Act 12 of 1955 has retrospective operation Refiquennessa v. Lal Bahadur Chetri Others, 1  and the only question to be determined in this appeal is whether a tenant qualifies for protection under s. 5 of the Act only after building permanent structures on the land of the tenancy if he occupies them for his own residential or business purposes.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the view taken by Mehrotra, J., because the Legislature has number, in companyferring rights of permanent tenancy, either expressly or by implication enacted any such qualification as is suggested by the learned Judge.
